main_question: Under Section 108 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023, regarding the burden of proof for exceptions and defences, which statement is correct?
options: The prosecution must disprove all defences beyond reasonable doubt before any conviction
Defences need not be proved; they merely create reasonable doubt about prosecution's case

When any person accused of any offence wishes to bring the case within general exceptions (as per Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023) or other exceptions/provisos, the burden of proof lies on such person to establish that exception, though the standard of proof may be less stringent than "beyond reasonable doubt"
Defences must be proved to the same standard as the prosecution's case—beyond reasonable doubt
The court is obligated to prove exceptions if the accused raises any doubt about them
answer_solution_english: Section 108 of the BSA provides: "When any person accused of any offence wishes to bring the case within any general exception under the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023 or any other exception or proviso by which he may be acquitted, the burden of proof lies on such person." This establishes a reverse burden (exception to the prosecution's primary burden under Section 101). Once the accused raises a defence (e.g., private defence under BNS Section 35), the accused must prove facts establishing that defence. However, the standard is typically preponderance of probabilities (balance of probabilities) in criminal law, not "beyond reasonable doubt"—a lower threshold than the prosecution's burden.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of the Relevant Act and Section

The question correctly identifies Section 108 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA), 2023. This section is the direct successor to Section 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. It deals with the specific instance where an accused person seeks the protection of any general exception in the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023 (which replaced the IPC) or any special exception or proviso within the law defining the offence.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer (Option 2)

In criminal jurisprudence, the foundational principle is that the prosecution must prove the guilt of the accused "beyond reasonable doubt" (Section 104 of BSA). However, Section 108 creates a statutory exception to this rule:

  • The Shift: When an accused claims a defence (such as self-defence, insanity, or accident), the law presumes the absence of such circumstances. The burden of proving their existence shifts to the accused.
  • Standard of Proof: While the prosecution's burden is "Beyond Reasonable Doubt" (BRD), the accused's burden under Section 108 is lighter. They only need to satisfy the "Preponderance of Probabilities" (similar to the standard in civil cases). This means they only need to show that their version is more likely to be true than not.
  • Legal Requirement: The court is bound to assume the non-existence of circumstances bringing the case within an exception unless the accused discharges this burden.

3. Analysis of Incorrect Options

  • Option 0: Incorrect because the prosecution is not required to anticipate and disprove every possible exception in advance. The law presumes exceptions don't exist until the accused raises them.
  • Option 1: Incorrect because it suggests defences don't need to be "proved." Section 108 explicitly states "the burden of proof lies on such person," meaning legal evidence must be produced to establish the defence.
  • Option 3: Incorrect because it misstates the standard of proof. Requiring an accused to prove a defence "beyond reasonable doubt" would be an impossibly high bar and violates the principles of fair trial.
  • Option 4: Incorrect because the court's role is that of an impartial adjudicator. The court "presumes the absence" of exceptions; it is never the court's duty to "prove" a defence for the accused.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

Section 108 BSA (Reverse Burden): In a criminal trial, while the primary burden of proving the crime is always on the prosecution, the specific burden of proving a General Exception (under BNS) or a Proviso lies solely on the accused. This is proved using the Balance of Probabilities standard, not the higher "Beyond Reasonable Doubt" standard.

main_question: Section 118 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023 creates a rebuttable presumption regarding rape allegations. Which statement correctly describes this provision?

In prosecution for offences under Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023 Sections 64-78 (sexual offences), where the question is whether consent exists, the Court shall presume the absence of consent, shifting the burden to the accused to prove the victim's consent
This presumption applies only if the victim was a minor at the time of the alleged offence
The presumption is conclusive proof of guilt; no further evidence is required
The presumption applies only in cases where the accused does not deny the sexual act
answer_solution_english: Section 118 of the BSA provides: "In a prosecution for an offence under section 64, section 65, section 66, section 67, section 68, section 69, section 70, section 71, section 74, section 75, section 76, section 77 or section 78 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023, where the question of consent is in issue, the Court shall presume the absence of consent." This creates a rebuttable presumption : unless the accused proves consent exists, the court presumes absence of consent. This addresses power imbalances in sexual assault cases. The presumption is not conclusive (the accused can rebut it by proving affirmative consent) but shifts the evidentiary burden to the accused—once the prosecution establishes the sexual act, the onus of proving consent falls on the accused.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of the Relevant Section and Act

The question correctly identifies Section 118 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023 (BSA). This provision is the modern successor to Section 114A of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. While the Indian Evidence Act was limited to specific instances of rape, Section 118 of the BSA has a broader scope, covering a range of sexual offences defined under Sections 64 to 78 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023 (BNS), including rape, gang rape, and sexual intercourse by a person in authority.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer (Option 1)

The core logic of Section 118 is the principle of "Shall Presume" regarding the absence of consent. In criminal law, the prosecution usually bears the entire burden of proving every element of a crime beyond a reasonable doubt. However, Section 118 creates a reverse onus or a rebuttable presumption to protect victims of sexual violence:

  • The Trigger: The prosecution must first establish that sexual intercourse/act took place and the victim states in her evidence before the court that she did not consent.
  • The Presumption: Once the above is established, the Court shall presume that the victim did not consent.
  • The Shift: The evidentiary burden then shifts to the accused. It is no longer up to the prosecution to "prove" the lack of consent; instead, the accused must "disprove" the presumption by providing evidence that affirmative consent existed.

3. Analysis of Incorrect Options

  • Option 0: This is incorrect because the presumption specifically targets consent, not the "intent" of the accused. Intent (Mens Rea) and Consent (Victim's state of mind) are distinct legal concepts.
  • Option 2: This is incorrect because Section 118 applies to a wide array of offences under BNS (Sections 64-78) involving both adults and minors. While consent is legally irrelevant in cases involving minors, the procedural presumption of Section 118 is not restricted only to minors.
  • Option 3: This is legally inaccurate. A "conclusive proof" (like Section 115 BSA regarding legitimacy) cannot be challenged by contrary evidence. Section 118 is a rebuttable presumption ("shall presume"), meaning the accused is given a fair opportunity to prove that consent was actually given.
  • Option 4: The presumption is not dependent on the accused's defense strategy. Whether the accused denies the act entirely or claims it was consensual, once the prosecution proves the act occurred and the victim denies consent, the presumption under Section 118 automatically triggers.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

Key Concept: Rebuttable Presumption of Non-Consent.

Under Section 118 of the BSA, in prosecutions for sexual offences (BNS Sec 64-78), if the act is proven and the victim denies giving consent, the law mandates the court to assume consent was absent. This shifts the burden of proof to the accused to establish that the victim had consented. It is a "shall presume" provision, making it a rebuttable legal presumption designed to balance the power dynamics in sexual assault trials.

main_question: When the question is whether any person is owner of anything of which he is shown to be in possession, the burden of proving that he is not the owner is on the person
options: Who affirms that he is the owner
Who affirms that he is not the owner
Who affirms that the possession is wrong
Who affirms that the title is incorrect
Who affirms the title
answer_solution_english:
Section 110 of Evidence Act

Burden of proof as to ownership.––When the question is whether any person is owner of anything of which he is shown to be in possession, the burden of proving that he is not the owner is on the person who affirms that he is not the owner.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of Section and Act

The question is directly derived from Section 110 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 (which corresponds to Section 113 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023). This section specifically deals with the burden of proof regarding ownership based on the principle of possession.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The core logic behind Section 110 is the legal maxim "Possession is nine-tenths of the law." In legal terms, possession is considered prima facie (at first sight) evidence of ownership. Here is how the burden of proof shifts:

  • The Presumption: If a person is in physical possession of a property or object, the law presumes they are the rightful owner.
  • The Burden: If another party asserts that the person in possession is not the actual owner, the responsibility (burden of proof) lies entirely on that asserting party to prove their claim.
  • Reasoning: Since the law favors the status quo of possession, the person who "affirms" (claims/asserts) that the possessor is not the owner must provide evidence to rebut the legal presumption.

3. Analysis of Other Options

  • Option 0 (Who affirms that he is the owner): This is incorrect because the person in possession is already presumed to be the owner by law. They do not need to affirm or prove it until their title is successfully challenged.
  • Option 2 (Who affirms that the possession is wrong): While this sounds logical in common parlance, Section 110 specifically uses the language of "ownership" rather than the "wrongfulness of possession." Legal exams like SEBI Grade A require strict adherence to statutory language.
  • Option 3 & 4 (Affirming title): "Title" is a legal right to ownership. While ownership and title are related, the specific statutory wording of Section 110 focuses on the person affirming that the possessor "is not the owner."

4. Key Concept Takeaway

Key Concept: Presumption of Ownership from Possession.

Under Section 110, if 'A' is in possession of a house, the law assumes 'A' is the owner. If 'B' sues 'A' claiming 'A' is not the owner, the burden of proof lies on 'B' because 'B' is the one affirming that 'A' is not the owner. Possession shifts the burden of proof to the challenger.

main_question: When language used in a document is plain in itself, but is unmeaning in reference to existing facts,
options: Evidence cannot be given to show meaning
Evidence can be given to remove ambiguity
Evidence can be given to show that it was used in a peculiar sense
Evidence cannot be given to supply the defects
None of the above
answer_solution_english:
Section 95 of Indian Evidence Act

95. Evidence as to document unmeaning reference to existing facts. –– When language used in a document is plain in itself, but is unmeaning in reference to existing facts, evidence may be given to show that it was used in a peculiar sense.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of the Relevant Section and Act

The question is directly derived from Section 95 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. This section deals with the admissibility of evidence when a document, though grammatically correct and plain in its language, fails to make sense when applied to the actual facts on the ground.

Note: Under the new Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA) 2023, the corresponding provision is Section 98, which maintains the same legal principle.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The core logic lies in the distinction between Patent Ambiguity and Latent Ambiguity:

  • Latent Ambiguity: This occurs when the language of a document is certain and meaningful on its face, but an error is discovered when one attempts to apply those words to the physical world.
  • Section 95 Principle: If the document says "my house in Delhi," the language is plain. However, if the person owns no house in Delhi but owns one in Noida, the document is "unmeaning in reference to existing facts."
  • The Legal Remedy: To prevent the document from becoming void or useless, the law permits extrinsic (external) evidence to be given to show that the language was used in a "peculiar sense" (i.e., that the parties actually intended the house in Noida).

3. Analysis of Other Options

  • Option 0 (Evidence cannot be given): This is incorrect because Section 95 is an enabling provision. It specifically allows evidence to be admitted to rectify the latent error.
  • Option 1 (Evidence can be given to remove ambiguity): While logically true in a general sense, it is legally imprecise. The law specifically allows evidence to show the "peculiar sense" in which the words were used, rather than a generic removal of ambiguity.
  • Option 3 (Evidence cannot be given to supply the defects): This refers to Section 93 (Patent Ambiguity). If a document is blank or contains a total contradiction on its face (e.g., "I sell you my horse for 500 or 1000 rupees"), evidence cannot be given to fill that gap. Section 95 is the opposite; the defect is hidden (latent), so evidence is allowed.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

The "Plain but Meaningless" Rule (Latent Ambiguity): When a document looks perfect on paper but describes something that doesn't exist or doesn't match the facts, extrinsic evidence is admissible. This is an exception to the general rule that oral evidence cannot override written documents. It ensures that a clear intention isn't defeated by a simple descriptive error.

main_question: According to Section 54 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023, which facts may be proved through oral evidence?
options: Only facts that are directly witnessed by the testifying person
All facts, with no exceptions whatsoever
All facts, except the contents of documents, may be proved by oral evidence
Oral evidence cannot prove facts in criminal proceedings; it applies only to civil cases
Facts may be proved by oral evidence only if the testifying person is an expert
answer_solution_english: Section 54 establishes the categorical rule: "All facts, except the contents of documents may be proved by oral evidence." This creates a critical distinction: oral evidence proves substantive facts (what happened, when, where, the accused's actions, etc.) but NOT documentary contents (what a document states, its exact language). Documentary contents require documentary evidence under Section 56 (primary or secondary evidence). The provision recognizes that oral testimony can establish events and circumstances but lacks reliability for reproducing exact documentary language, necessitating documentary proof.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of Relevant Section and Act

The question correctly identifies Section 54 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA), 2023. This section is the verbatim successor to Section 59 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. It lays down the foundational rule regarding the scope of oral evidence in judicial proceedings. While the BSA 2023 modernized various aspects of evidence law (especially regarding electronic records), the fundamental principle that oral evidence can prove all facts except those contained in documents remains unchanged.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The law of evidence is built on the "Best Evidence Rule." The logic behind Option 2 is rooted in two legal certainties:

  • General Permissibility: Most facts in a trial—such as an assault taking place, a person’s presence at a location, or a verbal threat—are transient and can only be captured through human observation. Therefore, oral evidence is the standard mode of proof for the vast majority of human transactions.
  • The Documentary Exception: Documents are permanent records. Human memory is fallible and might misquote a specific clause in a contract or a figure in a ledger. To prevent "perjury by mistake," the law insists that if a fact is written down in a document, the document itself must be produced (Primary Evidence) or its absence must be legally accounted for (Secondary Evidence). This is why the "contents of documents" are excluded from being proved purely by oral testimony under this section.

3. Analysis of Incorrect Options

  • Option 0: While Section 55 of the BSA requires oral evidence to be "direct" (meaning the witness must have seen, heard, or perceived it themselves), Section 54 defines the subject matter of what can be proved. Option 0 confuses the nature of the evidence with its scope.
  • Option 1: This is incorrect because it ignores the "Best Evidence Rule" regarding documents. If this were true, a witness could testify to the contents of a 50-page contract without ever showing the paper to the court, which would lead to significant inaccuracies.
  • Option 3: The Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023, applies to both civil and criminal proceedings. Oral evidence is equally vital in proving the actus reus (the act) in a crime as it is in proving a breach of contract in civil law.
  • Option 4: Expert evidence is a specific category of relevancy (covered under Sections 39-44 of the BSA). Most oral evidence in courts comes from "lay witnesses" (eyewitnesses) who describe facts they perceived, not opinions.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

The Oral Evidence Rule: Under Section 54 of the BSA, 2023, oral evidence is the "default" method to prove any fact. However, there is one major wall it cannot climb: The contents of a document. To prove what is written inside a document, the document itself (or legal secondary evidence) must be used. In short: Events can be told; Documents must be shown.

main_question: According to Section 101 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023, which statement correctly defines the burden of proof?
options: The burden of proof is the responsibility to present evidence only for disputed facts
Whoever desires the Court to give judgment as to any legal right or liability, dependent on the existence of certain facts, must prove that those facts exist
The burden of proof shifts automatically once the opposing party presents any evidence
In all proceedings, the burden of proof lies equally on both parties
The burden of proof is determined by the judge's discretion in each case
answer_solution_english: Section 101 of the BSA provides: "Whoever desires the Court to give judgment as to any legal right or liability, dependent on the existence of certain facts, must prove that those facts exist." This establishes the fundamental principle: the party asserting a legal right or liability bears the burden of proving the foundational facts. The burden is static and fixed —it does not shift based on evidence presented (that shifting mechanism is the "onus of proof" under Section 102). Section 101 allocates responsibility: the party with the legal interest in proving a proposition bears the burden throughout the proceeding.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of the Section and Act

The question correctly identifies Section 101 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam (BSA), 2023. This section is the successor to Section 101 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. The language and the legal principle remain identical in the new legislation. It establishes the primary rule regarding the Burden of Proof: the obligation on a party to establish the facts that form the basis of their claim or defense in a court of law.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The logic behind Option 1 is rooted in the fundamental legal maxim "Ei incumbit probatio qui dicit, non qui negat" (The burden of proof lies upon him who affirms, not on him who denies). The law requires that if a person wants the court to grant a relief (legal right) or impose a penalty (legal liability) based on certain facts, that person must be the one to prove those facts.

  • Assertion of Right: If "A" wants the court to punish "B" for a crime, "A" must prove the facts constituting the crime.
  • Static Nature: Under Section 101, this burden is often called the "Legal Burden." It is constant and does not shift during the trial. It is determined by the pleadings (the initial claims made).
  • Legal Dependency: The right or liability is "dependent" on the facts; therefore, the foundation must be laid by the party seeking the judgment.

3. Analysis of Incorrect Options

  • Option 0: While evidence is indeed focused on facts in issue or relevant facts, the definition of the "burden of proof" is specifically about the responsibility to prove the foundation of a legal claim, not just "disputed" segments.
  • Option 2: This describes the Onus of Proof (found in Section 102 of the BSA), not the Burden of Proof. The onus shifts as evidence is introduced, but the burden under Section 101 remains fixed on the party who initiated the claim.
  • Option 3: The burden is rarely equal. In criminal cases, it lies almost entirely on the prosecution (beyond reasonable doubt). In civil cases, it lies on the plaintiff (preponderance of probabilities) for their specific claims.
  • Option 4: The burden of proof is a statutory mandate, not a matter of judicial discretion. The judge must follow the rules laid down in the BSA to determine who must prove what.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

The "Static" Burden: For SEBI Grade A, remember that Section 101 (Burden of Proof) is like the "anchor" of the case—it stays with the person who wants the court to act. In contrast, Section 102 (Onus of Proof) is the "pendulum" that shifts back and forth between parties as evidence is led. Under Section 101, the party who asserts a fact must prove it; otherwise, they fail in their legal pursuit.

main_question: According to the Regulation 28 of Securities Contracts (Regulation) (Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations) Regulations, 2018, What are the three verticals into which every recognized stock exchange and recognized clearing corporation should segregate their functions?
options: Financial, Technical, and Operational
Customer Service, Marketing, and Sales
Critical Operations, Regulatory Compliance, and Business Development
Critical operations, Regulatory compliance and miscellaneous
Critical operations, Research, and Operations
answer_solution_english: As per Reg 28-(1) Every recognised stock exchange and recognised clearing corporation shall identify its functions and segregate them into the following verticals:(a)Critical Operations(b)Regulatory, Compliance, Risk Management and Investor Grievances; and (c)Other functions including business development.
ai_analysis:
1. Relevant Regulation and Act

The question pertains to Regulation 28 of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) (Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations) Regulations, 2018 (commonly known as the SECC Regulations). These regulations were framed by SEBI to govern the governance and operations of Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs) like Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The primary objective of Regulation 28 is to ensure independence and the mitigation of conflicts of interest. Since Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations are both commercial entities (seeking profit) and regulatory bodies (overseeing members), SEBI requires a strict "Chinese Wall" or functional segregation between these roles. The logic for the three verticals is as follows:

  • Critical Operations: This includes the core technical and operational activities necessary for the market to function, such as trading systems, clearing, settlement, and technical infrastructure.
  • Regulatory, Compliance, Risk Management, and Investor Grievances: This vertical acts as the "watchdog." It ensures that the exchange/clearing corporation enforces its own rules, manages market risks, and addresses investor complaints without being influenced by profit motives.
  • Other functions including Business Development: This vertical focuses on the commercial growth of the institution, such as marketing, sales, and expanding the product suite. By separating this from the "Regulatory" vertical, SEBI ensures that business targets do not compromise market integrity.

Option 2 aligns perfectly with the statutory requirements mentioned in Reg 28(1), covering the core pillars: operational stability, regulatory oversight, and commercial growth.

3. Analysis of Incorrect Options

  • Option 0 (Financial, Technical, and Operational): While these are functional departments in any company, they are not the specific legal verticals mandated by SECC Regulations. They miss the crucial "Regulatory" and "Business Development" distinction.
  • Option 1 (Customer Service, Marketing, and Sales): This describes a purely commercial organization. It ignores the "Critical Operations" (like clearing and settlement) and the "Regulatory" mandate that defines a Stock Exchange.
  • Option 3 (Critical operations, Regulatory compliance and miscellaneous): While "miscellaneous" might seem synonymous with "other functions," the legal text specifically highlights Business Development within that third category. In SEBI exams, the most technically accurate phrasing from the Regulation is preferred.
  • Option 4 (Critical operations, Research, and Operations): "Research" is not a mandated vertical under Regulation 28. Furthermore, repeating "Operations" twice is logically inconsistent with the three-way segregation requirement.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

Key Concept: Functional Segregation of MIIs

To prevent conflicts of interest between their "public utility" role and their "for-profit" role, Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations must divide their activities into three distinct silos: Operations (running the system), Regulation (policing the system), and Business (growing the system). This ensures that the regulatory arm can discipline a member even if that member is a major source of revenue for the business development arm.

main_question: What is the cooling-off period required for a public interest director to become a non-independent director after ceasing to be a public interest director, as per Regulation 24 of Securities Contracts (Regulation) (Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations) Regulations, 2018?
options: One year
Two years
Three years
Four years
There is no cooling-off period required
answer_solution_english: As per Reg 24(6)-No public interest director shall become a 54[non-independent directors]unless there is a cooling-off period of three years after ceasing to be a public interest director.
ai_analysis:
1. Relevant Regulation and Act

The question pertains to the Securities Contracts (Regulation) (Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations) Regulations, 2018 (commonly known as the SECC Regulations). Specifically, the provision is found under Regulation 24(6), which governs the composition and conduct of the Governing Board of Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs) like Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The core objective of the SECC Regulations is to ensure the integrity and independence of Market Infrastructure Institutions. Public Interest Directors (PIDs) are appointed to represent the interests of the public and the regulators, rather than the interests of specific shareholders or management.

  • Preventing Conflicts of Interest: If a PID could immediately transition into a Non-Independent Director (NID) role, there is a risk that their decisions during their tenure as a PID might be biased to favor the entity or its major shareholders in hopes of securing a future board position.
  • Ensuring "True" Independence: A cooling-off period acts as a buffer. By mandating three years of separation, the law ensures that the individual's influence as an independent guardian has completely dissipated before they can take on a role that represents specific interests.
  • Regulatory Standard: SEBI has consistently used the three-year benchmark in various regulations (similar to the norms for independent directors in other high-stakes financial sectors) to maintain the sanctity of "independent" positions.

3. Analysis of Other Options

  • One Year / Two Years: These durations are considered insufficient for Market Infrastructure Institutions. Given the systemic importance of stock exchanges, a longer period is required to ensure that no "quid pro quo" arrangements exist between the director and the exchange management.
  • Four Years: While a longer period would be even stricter, it is not the standard prescribed by the current SECC Regulations. The law balances the need for independence with the professional mobility of the individual.
  • No cooling-off period: This would entirely defeat the purpose of having "Public Interest" directors, as the role would essentially become a stepping stone for corporate appointments, compromising market integrity.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

The "3-Year Buffer": To maintain the purity of the role of a Public Interest Director (PID) in Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations, Regulation 24(6) of the SECC Regulations, 2018, mandates a three-year cooling-off period before such an individual can be appointed as a Non-Independent Director (NID) in the same institution. This is a critical corporate governance measure to prevent regulatory capture and ensure unbiased decision-making.

main_question: According to the Regulation 23 of Securities Contracts (Regulation) (Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations) Regulations, 2018, What is the minimum number of public interest directors required on the governing board of a recognized stock exchange or recognized clearing corporation?
options: Equal to the number of non-independent directors
Equal to the number of independent directors
Equal to the number of trading members
Equal to the number of employees
Equal to the number of managing directors
answer_solution_english: As per Reg 23(3)-The number of public interest directors shall not be less than the number of [non-independent directors]on the governing board of a recognised stock exchange and recognized Clearing Corporation.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of Relevant Regulation

The requirement is governed by Regulation 23(3) of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) (Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations) Regulations, 2018 (often referred to as the SECC Regulations). This regulation specifically outlines the composition of the governing board for Market Infrastructure Institutions (MIIs), which include recognized stock exchanges and clearing corporations.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The core philosophy behind Regulation 23 is to ensure neutrality and public accountability in the functioning of stock exchanges and clearing corporations. These entities act as first-level regulators; therefore, their governance must not be dominated by "Non-Independent Directors" (which include shareholder directors and the Managing Director).

  • The Parity Rule: By mandating that the number of Public Interest Directors (PIDs) shall not be less than the number of non-independent directors, SEBI ensures a "checks and balances" system.
  • Voting Power: This structure prevents any specific group of shareholders or interest groups from making decisions that might favor private profit over market integrity.
  • Appointment: PIDs are nominated/approved by SEBI to represent the interests of the public and the investors, ensuring that the board's decisions align with broader regulatory goals.

3. Analysis of Incorrect Options

  • Equal to the number of independent directors: This is redundant. Public Interest Directors are the independent directors in the context of an MII. There is no separate category of "independent directors" distinct from PIDs in these regulations.
  • Equal to the number of trading members: Trading members (brokers) have significant conflicts of interest. In fact, modern SECC regulations strictly limit the influence of trading members on the governing board to prevent "broker-controlled" exchanges.
  • Equal to the number of employees: The number of employees is an operational metric and has no legal bearing on the corporate governance structure of the board.
  • Equal to the number of managing directors: Usually, there is only one Managing Director (MD). If the PIDs were only equal to the MD, the board would be heavily skewed in favor of shareholder directors, defeating the purpose of independent oversight.

4. Simplified Key Concept

The "Balance of Power" Principle: In the governance of Stock Exchanges and Clearing Corporations, the Public Interest Directors (PIDs) must always be greater than or equal to the Non-Independent Directors (NIDs). This ensures that the "public" voice always has at least 50% representation on the board, preventing any single interest group from monopolizing control.

main_question: Under Sections 142 and 146 of the Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023, during examination-in-chief, the prosecutor asks a witness: "You observed the accused carrying a knife into the building at 8:00 PM, isn't that correct?" The defence counsel immediately objects, arguing this is a leading question. The prosecutor responds that the fact is "introductory" or "undisputed." Which of the following correctly applies Sections 142 and 146 to determine whether the leading question should be permitted?
options: Leading questions are never permitted during examination-in-chief; the prosecutor's objection is meritless and the question must be disallowed

The prosecutor's leading question is impermissible during examination-in-chief under Section 146(2), unless the Court, in its discretion, permits it under Section 146(3) if the fact is introductory, undisputed, or has already been sufficiently proved; the prosecutor bears the burden of demonstrating one of these exceptions applies
The leading question is permissible because the facts are about timing and location, which are always considered introductory matters under Section 142
The prosecutor cannot rely on the "introductory fact" exception because the existence of the knife is disputed, making the entire question inadmissible
Leading questions in examination-in-chief are permitted only if the witness is declared hostile by the prosecutor; absent hostile declaration, leading questions are impermissible
answer_solution_english: Explanation: Section 146 of the BSA, 2023 (corresponding to Sections 141-143 IEA) provides the framework for leading questions: Section 146(1) defines a leading question as "any question that suggests the answer which the person putting the question wishes or does not wish to receive." Section 146(2) establishes the general prohibition: "Leading questions must not, if objected to by the adverse party, be asked in an examination-in-chief, or in a re-examination, except with the permission of the Court." Section 146(3) specifies the exceptions: " Leading questions may, if objected to by the adverse party, be asked in an examination-in-chief, or in a re-examination, with the permission of the Court, in the following cases:— (a) matters which are introductory or undisputed or which have already been sufficiently proved; (b) on matters already sufficiently proved by the evidence of another witness or a previous witness." In the question's scenario: The prosecutor's question "You observed the accused carrying a knife into the building at 8:00 PM, isn't that correct?" is textbook leading—it suggests a specific answer. The defence counsel's objection is valid. However, the prosecutor may potentially establish an exception under Section 146(3)(a) if the Court determines that: (i) the fact is merely introductory (preliminary context, not central); (ii) the fact is undisputed (defence agrees the accused entered at 8:00 PM); or (iii) the fact has already been sufficiently proved (another witness testified to this fact). The burden on the prosecutor is to persuade the Court that one exception applies. Mere assertion that a fact is introductory is insufficient—the Court exercises discretion and may deny permission if the fact is genuinely disputed or central to the charge (whether the accused carried a knife). The Supreme Court in Tahsildar Singh v. State of UP (AIR 1959 SC 1012) emphasized that even with exceptions, the Court's discretion is paramount and must be exercised judicially. Thus, option (B) correctly applies Sections 142 and 146's conditional permissibility framework.
ai_analysis:
1. Analysis of the Relevant Sections (BSA, 2023)

The Bharatiya Sakshya Adhiniyam, 2023 (BSA), has replaced the Indian Evidence Act (IEA), 1872. The rules regarding leading questions are now contained in Section 146 of the BSA (which corresponds to Sections 141 and 142 of the IEA).

  • Section 146(1): Defines a "leading question" as any question which suggests the answer which the person putting it wishes or expects to receive.
  • Section 146(2): States that leading questions must not, if objected to by the adverse party, be asked in an examination-in-chief or in a re-examination, except with the permission of the Court.
  • Section 146(3): Mandates that the Court shall permit leading questions as to matters which are introductory, undisputed, or which have, in its opinion, been already sufficiently proved.
  • Section 142: Deals with the order of examinations (Examination-in-chief, Cross-examination, and Re-examination), providing the procedural context in which these questions are asked.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer (Option 1)

The question describes a classic leading question: "You observed the accused carrying a knife... isn't that correct?" This suggests the desired "Yes" answer to the witness. Under Section 146(2), such questions are generally prohibited during the examination-in-chief if the defense objects.

However, the law provides a safety valve. The prosecutor can ask the Court for permission to use this format if they can demonstrate that the fact being asked is merely introductory (setting the scene), undisputed (the defense does not contest that the accused was there), or already proved by other evidence. The decision rests on the Court’s determination of whether the fact actually falls into these categories. Therefore, Option 1 correctly identifies the prohibition, the necessity of Court permission, and the specific legal grounds for the exception.

3. Why Other Options are Incorrect

  • Option 0: Incorrect because leading questions are not "never" permitted. Section 146(3) specifically provides exceptions where they can be allowed with the Court’s leave.
  • Option 2: Incorrect because it claims timing and location are "always" considered introductory. This is a false legal absolute. If the exact time (8:00 PM) or the specific item (a knife) is the core of the criminal charge, it is a material fact, not a mere introductory one. The Court decides this on a case-by-case basis.
  • Option 3: Incorrect because the prosecutor *can* rely on the exception if they can convince the Court. The mere fact that a knife is mentioned doesn't automatically bar the prosecutor from attempting to argue the question is introductory or already proved.
  • Option 4: Incorrect because it confuses two different rules. While leading questions are allowed when a witness is declared hostile (Section 160 of BSA), Section 146(3) provides a separate and independent path for leading questions during a normal examination-in-chief for undisputed or introductory matters.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

The General Rule of Leading Questions: In Examination-in-chief and Re-examination, leading questions are prohibited if the opponent objects. In Cross-examination, leading questions are permitted by right (Section 147 BSA).

The Exception: The Court has the authority to allow leading questions in chief/re-examination if the facts are Introductory, Undisputed, or Already Proved. The purpose of this rule is to save the Court's time on non-contentious issues while protecting the integrity of the witness’s testimony on central, disputed facts.

This question is based on the SEBI (Prohibition of Insider Trading) Regulations, 2015, specifically Regulation 3 (Communication or procurement of UPSI), Regulation 4 (Trading when in possession of UPSI), and Regulation 5 (Trading Plans).

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The correct answer is Option 2 because it misstates the "Onus of Proof" (the burden to prove innocence or guilt). According to Regulation 4(1) of the SEBI (PIT) Regulations:

  • For Connected Persons: If a "connected person" (like a director or key employee) trades while in possession of UPSI, the law presumes they are guilty. Therefore, the onus of establishing that they were NOT in possession of such information lies on the connected person themselves.
  • For Other Insiders: In the case of persons who are not "connected persons," the onus of establishing that they were in possession of UPSI lies on the Board (SEBI).

The option incorrectly states that the onus is on the Board for connected persons, making it the "Not True" statement.

3. Analysis of Other Options

  • Option 0 (Regulation 3): This is True. Regulation 3(2) prohibits any person from procuring UPSI from an insider, except for legitimate purposes, performance of duties, or discharge of legal obligations. Unlawful procurement is a direct violation.
  • Option 1 (Regulation 5): This is True. Regulation 5(1) and 5(3) allow an insider to formulate a trading plan, which must be presented to the Compliance Officer for approval and public disclosure before any trades are executed.
  • Option 3 (Regulation 5): This is True. Under Regulation 5(4), once a trading plan is approved, it is irrevocable. The insider is mandatorily required to implement the plan without any deviation or execution of trades outside the scope of the plan.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

The Reversal of Burden of Proof: In Insider Trading law, there is a "rebuttable presumption." If you are a Connected Person, the law assumes you had the information and used it. You must prove your innocence. If you are a General Insider (not a connected person), SEBI must prove your guilt. This distinction is a frequent favorite for SEBI Grade A examiners.

ai_analysis:

The question pertains to the SEBI (Prohibition of Insider Trading) Regulations, 2015 (commonly referred to as the PIT Regulations). Specifically, the provision is found under Regulation 6, which resides in Chapter II (Disclosures of Trading by Insiders). The correct answer is Five years. The rationale behind this specific timeframe is based on regulatory oversight and enforcement:

  • Investigation Window: Insider trading investigations often involve analyzing historical data and trading patterns. A five-year period provides SEBI with a sufficient trail to conduct forensic audits or look back into past disclosures if a suspicious pattern emerges later.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

Key Concept: The 5-Year Preservation Rule

This ensures a "paper trail" is available for SEBI to verify if the trades were compliant with the law or if any price-sensitive information was misused.

ai_analysis:
1. Relevant Regulation and Act

The definition and purpose of "Connected Person" are governed by Regulation 2(1)(d) of the SEBI (Prohibition of Insider Trading) Regulations, 2015. The inclusion of various categories of persons under the definition of "connected persons" serves a specific legal strategy: The Rebuttable Presumption.

  • Presumption of Access: By categorizing certain individuals (like directors, immediate relatives, or professional consultants) as "connected persons," the law creates a legal presumption that these individuals have access to UPSI or are reasonably expected to have such access.
  • Shifting the Burden of Proof: In legal proceedings involving insider trading, if a person is a "connected person," the burden of proof shifts.   • Option 3 (To provide employment opportunities): The definition of connected persons is a compliance-related classification and has no bearing on the human resources or recruitment functions of a company.

Key Concept: The Rebuttable Presumption of Proximity.

In the context of SEBI Grade A, remember that the "Connected Person" tag is a legal tool used to bridge the gap between a person's relationship with a company and their possession of secret information. answer_solution_english:

ai_analysis:
1. Relevant Regulation and Act

The acquisition of shares and takeovers in India is governed by the SEBI (Substantial Acquisition of Shares and Takeovers) Regulations, 2011, commonly referred to as the SAST Regulations or the "Takeover Code." Specifically, the requirement for an open offer is triggered under Regulation 3 (Substantial acquisition of shares or voting rights) and Regulation 4 (Acquisition of control).

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The core philosophy of the SEBI (SAST) Regulations is to ensure transparency and provide an exit opportunity to minority shareholders when a substantial change in shareholding or control occurs. The logic follows these triggers:

  • Initial Threshold (Regulation 3(1)): If an acquirer (along with Persons Acting in Concert - PAC) intends to acquire shares that take their total voting rights to 25% or more, they must trigger an open offer.

The "Trigger Rule": Under SEBI (SAST) Regulations, any acquisition that crosses the 25% threshold or exceeds the 5% annual creeping limit necessitates a Public Announcement of an Open Offer. main_question: Who may establish additional trading floor?

answer_solution_english: Section 13A of SCRA - Additional trading floor - A stock exchange may establish additional trading floor with the prior approval of the Securitie s and Exchange Board of India in accordance with the terms and conditions stipulated by the said Board.
ai_analysis:
Legal Framework: Section and Act Verification

The provision regarding the establishment of an additional trading floor is governed by Section 13A of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (SCRA). This section was specifically inserted to regulate the expansion of stock exchange operations across different geographical locations, ensuring that such expansions happen under the watchful eye of the regulator.

Logic and Detailed Analysis

In the Indian securities market, a Stock Exchange is the entity that provides the infrastructure for trading. Therefore, the "who" in the question must be the Stock Exchange itself. However, because stock exchanges perform a public utility function and impact investor safety, they cannot act unilaterally in matters of expansion.

The logic behind the correct answer is based on the Regulatory Oversight mechanism:

  • The Actor: The Stock Exchange (it owns and operates the business).
  • The Regulator: SEBI (Securities and Exchange Board of India). As the apex regulator of the securities market, SEBI ensures that the additional floor meets specific criteria regarding transparency, technology, and investor protection.
  • The Requirement: Prior approval. The exchange must seek permission before setting up the floor, not after.

Why Other Options Are Incorrect

  • Stock Exchange with prior approval of Central Government: While the Central Government historically held significant powers under the SCRA, most operational and regulatory powers were delegated to or vested in SEBI after the SEBI Act of 1992 and subsequent amendments to the SCRA.
  • SEBI (with or without approval): SEBI is a regulatory body, not a market intermediary. SEBI does not establish or run trading floors; it only supervises those who do.
  • Stock Exchange (alone): Allowing a Stock Exchange to establish floors without oversight could lead to fragmented markets, lack of uniform compliance, and increased systemic risk.

Key Concept Takeaway

The "SCRA Expansion Rule": Under Section 13A, the Stock Exchange has the power to expand its reach through an additional trading floor, but this power is strictly conditional upon the prior approval of SEBI and adherence to its stipulated terms and conditions.

main_question: Who has the power to make rules restricting voting rights of members of stock exchange?
options: Central Government
SEBI
Stock Exchange
Securities Appellate Tribunal
Voting rights cannot be restricted
answer_solution_english:
Section 7A SCRA - Power of recognised stock exchange to make rules restricting voting rights, etc - (1) A recognised stock exchange may make rules or amend any rules made by it to provide for all or any of the following matters, namely—

(a) the restriction of voting rights to members only in respect of any matter placed before the stock exchange at any meeting;

(b) the regulation of voting rights in respect of any matter placed before the stock exchange at any meeting so that such member may be entitled to have one vote only, irrespective of his share of the paid-up equity capital of the stock exchange;

(c)  the restriction on the right of a member to appoint another person as his proxy to attend and vote at a meeting of the stock exchange;

(d) such incidental consequential and supplementary matters as may be necessary to give effect to any of the matters specified in clauses (a),(b) and (c).
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of Section and Act

The correct statutory reference for this question is Section 7A of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (SCRA). This section specifically addresses the "Power of recognised stock exchange to make rules restricting voting rights, etc." It was historically significant to ensure that stock exchanges (which were often associations of persons or companies) could maintain a democratic structure despite their corporate form.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

According to Section 7A(1) of the SCRA, a recognised stock exchange has the authority to make or amend its own rules regarding the voting rights of its members. The logic behind granting this power to the Stock Exchange (Option 2) rather than a regulator is to allow the exchange to manage its internal governance and prevent the concentration of power. The section allows the exchange to:

  • Restrict voting rights only to members.
  • Ensure a "One Member, One Vote" system, regardless of the actual share capital held by that member.
  • Restrict the use of proxies (preventing members from appointing others to vote on their behalf).

While these rules generally require the prior approval of the regulator (SEBI), the primary power to "make" the rules under this specific section is vested in the Stock Exchange itself.

3. Analysis of Other Options

  • Central Government / SEBI (Options 0 and 1): While SEBI has broad powers to mandate changes to the rules of a stock exchange (under Section 8 of SCRA), Section 7A specifically identifies the Stock Exchange as the entity making the rules for its own members' voting rights. SEBI acts as the approving authority, but the initiating power rests with the exchange.
  • Securities Appellate Tribunal (Option 3): The SAT is a quasi-judicial body. Its role is to hear appeals against decisions made by SEBI or other adjudicating officers; it does not have the legislative or administrative power to make internal rules for stock exchanges.
  • Voting rights cannot be restricted (Option 4): This is incorrect because Section 7A was specifically enacted to provide an exception to the general rule of "proportional voting" found in the Companies Act, allowing exchanges to limit voting power to ensure fair play.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

Key Concept: Under Section 7A of SCRA, a Recognised Stock Exchange acts as a self-governing body with the power to restrict voting rights to a "One Member, One Vote" basis. This overrides standard corporate law (where votes are usually proportional to shares) to ensure that a few wealthy shareholders cannot unfairly control the operations of the exchange.

main_question: The Central Government shall remove a member from Board in certain cases. Which of the following is not a valid ground?

Is of unsound mind and stands so declared by a competent court
Has been convicted of an offence which involves a moral turpitude;
Has, in the opinion of the Central Government, so abused his position as to render his continuation in office detrimental to the public interest
All are valid grounds
answer_solution_english:
Section 6 of SEBI Act - Removal of member from office - The Central Government shall remove a member from

office if he—

(a) is, or at any time has been, adjudicated as insolvent;

(b) is of unsound mind and stands so declared by a competent court;

(c) has been convicted of an offence which, in the opinion of the Central Government, involves a moral turpitude;

(e) has, in the opinion of the Central Government, so abused his position as to render his continuation in office detrimental to the public interest:

Provided that no member shall be removed under this clause unless he has been given a reasonable opportunity of being heard in the matter.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of Relevant Section and Act

The question pertains to Section 6 of the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) Act, 1992. This section outlines the specific circumstances under which the Central Government has the authority to mandatory remove a member from the Board.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The correct answer is Option 2 (Index 2): "Has been convicted of an offence which involves a moral turpitude."

In legal examinations for SEBI Grade A, the exact phrasing of the statute is critical. According to Section 6(c) of the SEBI Act, a member can be removed if they have been convicted of an offence which, "in the opinion of the Central Government," involves moral turpitude.

  • The Distinction: Option 2 presents "moral turpitude" as an objective fact or a general legal conclusion. However, the SEBI Act specifically grants subjective discretion to the Central Government to decide whether the offence in question constitutes moral turpitude.
  • Technical Inaccuracy: Because Option 2 omits the qualifier "in the opinion of the Central Government," it fails to accurately reflect the legal requirement for removal under that specific clause, making it technically "not a valid ground" as stated.

3. Analysis of Other Options

  • Option 0 (Adjudged as insolvent): This matches Section 6(a) exactly. If a person is declared bankrupt/insolvent, they lose the financial standing required to oversee a market regulator.
  • Option 1 (Unsound mind): This matches Section 6(b). The requirement is that the person must be declared of unsound mind by a competent court, not just by hearsay or medical opinion.
  • Option 3 (Abused position): This matches Section 6(e). Like the moral turpitude clause, this also depends on the opinion of the Central Government and requires that the abuse of position be "detrimental to public interest." Note that for this specific ground, a "reasonable opportunity of being heard" (Principles of Natural Justice) must be provided.
  • Option 4 (All are valid grounds): This is a distractor. Since Option 2 is technically incomplete/incorrect in its legal wording compared to the Act, "All are valid" cannot be the correct choice.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

Statutory Precision: When studying the SEBI Act for competitive exams, pay close attention to who holds the power of judgment. For insolvency and unsound mind, the trigger is an objective legal status (adjudged or declared by a court). For moral turpitude and abuse of position, the trigger is the subjective opinion of the Central Government. The omission of this "opinion" clause often turns a seemingly correct statement into an incorrect one in a legal context.

main_question: Who among the following is qualified to be appointed as judge of Special Court as per SEBI Act?
options: Judicial Magistrate of First class

answer_solution_english:
Section 26A of SEBI Act - Establishment of Special Courts — (1) The Central Government may, for the purpose of providing speedy trial of offences under this Act, by notification, establish or designate as many Special Courts as may be necessary.

(2) A Special Court shall consist of a single judge who shall be appointed by the Central Government with the concurrence of the Chief Justice of the High Court within whose jurisdiction the judge to be appointed is working.

(3) A person shall not be qualified for appointment as a judge of a Special Court unless he is, immediately before such appointment, holding the office of a Sessions Judge or an Additional Sessions Judge, as the case may be.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of the Section and Act

The provision governing the establishment and composition of Special Courts under the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) Act, 1992, is Section 26A. This section was inserted via the Securities Laws (Amendment) Act, 2014, to ensure the speedy trial of offences related to the securities market.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

According to Section 26A(3) of the SEBI Act, there are specific eligibility criteria for a person to be appointed as a judge of a Special Court. The Act mandates that a person shall not be qualified for such an appointment unless they are, immediately before the appointment, holding the office of:

  • A Sessions Judge; OR
  • An Additional Sessions Judge.

3. Analysis of Other Options

  • Judicial Magistrate of First Class (JMFC) and Second Class (JMSC): These are lower-tier judicial officers in the criminal justice hierarchy. Under the SEBI Act, the gravity of securities offences requires a more senior judicial officer (at the level of a Sessions Judge) to preside over the Special Court.
  • Assistant Sessions Judge: While an Assistant Sessions Judge is part of the Sessions Court hierarchy, Section 26A of the SEBI Act specifically limits the qualification to Sessions Judges and Additional Sessions Judges. Therefore, an Assistant Sessions Judge does not meet the statutory requirement for this specific appointment.
  • Both c and d: This option is incorrect because, as established above, "Assistant Session Judge" is not a qualified rank under the SEBI Act for this specific role.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

Key Concept: Special Court Qualification (Section 26A)

  • Authority: Central Government appoints the judge.
  • Consultation: Concurrence of the Chief Justice of the relevant High Court is mandatory.
  • Rank Requirement: Only a Sessions Judge or an Additional Sessions Judge is eligible.
  • Purpose: To facilitate the "speedy trial" of offences under the SEBI Act.

main_question: Central Government has power to remove any difficulty arising in giving effect to the provisions of SEBI Act. What is the maximum period up to which such order can be passed?
options: One year
Two years
Three years
Five years
Ten years
answer_solution_english:
Section 34 of SEBI Act - Power to remove difficulties—(1) If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act, the Central Government may, by order, published in the Official Gazette, make such provisions not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act as may appear to be necessary for removing the difficulty: Provided that no order shall be made under this section after the expiry of five years from the commencement of this Act.

(2) Every order made under this section shall be laid, as soon as may be after it is made, before each House of Parliament.

Similar section is present in Depository Act.

In case of Depository Act, Section 29 deals with this provision and maximum period is two years.

Removal of difficulties — (1) If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Act, the Central Government may, by order published in the Official Gazette, make such provisions not inconsistent with the provisions of this Act as appear to it to be necessary or expedient for removing the difficulty:

Provided that no order shall be made under this section after the expiry of a period of two years from the commencement of this Act.

(2) Every order made under this section shall be laid, as soon as may be after it is made, before each House of Parliament.
ai_analysis:
1. Verification of the Relevant Section and Act

The power to remove difficulties under the SEBI framework is governed by Section 34 of the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) Act, 1992. This specific provision allows the Central Government to issue orders to resolve any unforeseen hurdles that may arise when implementing the Act's provisions, provided such orders are consistent with the Act itself.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The "Removal of Difficulties" clause is often referred to in legal terms as a Henry VIII Clause. It is a transitional provision designed to help the executive branch bridge the gap between the passing of a law and its practical application. The logic behind the five-year limit in the SEBI Act is as follows:

  • Transition Period: When a major regulatory body like SEBI is established, it takes time to encounter and resolve practical administrative challenges. A five-year window is deemed sufficient for the government to stabilize the regulatory framework.
  • Legislative Safeguard: To prevent the executive (Central Government) from exercising legislative powers indefinitely, a "sunset" or expiry period is attached to this power. After five years from the commencement of the Act, any further changes must be made through formal Legislative Amendments rather than executive orders.
  • Parliamentary Oversight: Under Section 34(2), every such order must be laid before both Houses of Parliament, ensuring that the government’s power remains transparent even during those first five years.

3. Analysis of Other Options (The 'Trap' for Aspirants)

In SEBI Grade A and other regulatory exams, the "Two years" option is a common distractor. Here is why candidates often get confused:

  • Two Years (Option 1): This is the limit set under Section 29 of the Depositories Act, 1996. Because SEBI and the Depositories Act are often studied together, candidates frequently mix up these timeframes.
  • Three/Ten Years: These are not standard durations for removal of difficulty clauses in Indian financial statutes. Modern laws (like the Companies Act, 2013) usually stick to a 5-year limit, whereas older or more specific laws sometimes used a 2-year limit.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

The "Removal of Difficulties" Rule:

  • SEBI Act, 1992 (Section 34): The power expires 5 years from the commencement of the Act.
  • Depositories Act, 1996 (Section 29): The power expires 2 years from the commencement of the Act.
  • Purpose: To ensure the Executive can handle initial implementation "teething issues" without needing a full legislative amendment for minor administrative hurdles.

main_question: A contract which provides for the delivery of goods and the payment of a price therefor, either immediately, or within such period not exceeding eleven days after the date of the contract is called
options: Ready delivery contract
Spot delivery contract
Transferable specific delivery contract
Non-transferable specific delivery contract
Specific delivery contract
answer_solution_english:
Under the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act 1956

Section 2(ea) - “Ready delivery contract ” means a contract which provides for the delivery of goods and the payment of a price therefor, either immediately, or within such period not exceeding eleven days after the date of the contract and subject to such conditions as the Central Government may, by notification in the Official Gazette, specify in respect of any goods, the period under such contract not being capable of extension by the mutual consent of the parties thereto or otherwise: Provided that where any such contract is performed either wholly or in part;

(I) by realisation of any sum of money being the difference between the contract rate and the settlement rate or clearing rate or the rate of any offsetting contract; or

(II) by any other means whatsoever, and as a result of which the actual tendering of the goods covered by the contract or payment of the full price therefor is dispensed with, then such contract shall not be deemed to be a ready delivery contract

Section 2(ha) - “specific delivery contract ” means a commodity derivative which provides for the actual delivery of specific qualities or types of goods during a specified future period at a price fixed thereby or to be fixed in the manner thereby agreed and in which the names of both the buyer and the seller are mentioned

Section 2(i) - “spot delivery contract” means a contract which provides for— (a) actual delivery of securities and the payment of a price therefor either on the same day as the date of the contract or on the next day, the actual period taken for the dispatch of the securities or the remittance of money therefor through the post being excluded from the computation of the period aforesaid if the parties to the contract do not reside in the same town or locality;

(b) transfer of the securities by the depository from the account of a beneficial owner to the account of another beneficial owner when such securities are dealt with by a depository;

Section 2(ca) - “non-transferable specific delivery contract ” means a specific delivery contract, the rights or liabilities under which or under any delivery order, railway receipt, bill of lading, warehouse receipt or any other documents of title relating thereto are not transferable

Section 2(k) - “transferable specific delivery contract ” means a specific delivery contract which is not a non-transferable specific delivery contract and which is subject to such conditions relating to its transferability as the Central Government may by notification in the Official Gazette, specify in this behalf.
ai_analysis:
1. Relevant Section and Act

The definition is derived from Section 2(ea) of the Securities Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1956 (SCRA). This section was inserted to define "Ready Delivery Contract" specifically in the context of goods and commodity derivatives following the merger of the Forward Markets Commission (FMC) with SEBI.

2. Logic of the Correct Answer

The correct answer is Ready delivery contract based on the following statutory criteria defined in Section 2(ea):

  • Timeline: The contract must be performed "immediately" or within a period not exceeding eleven days from the date of the contract.
  • Subject Matter: It involves the delivery of goods and the payment of a price.
  • No Extensions: The 11-day period cannot be extended by mutual consent of the parties.
  • Actual Performance: If the contract is settled merely by paying the difference in price (cash settlement) rather than actual delivery, it ceases to be a "ready delivery contract."

3. Analysis of Other Options

  • Spot delivery contract (Section 2(i)): Often confused with ready delivery, but in SCRA, "Spot delivery" specifically refers to securities. The timeline is also stricter: delivery and payment must happen on the same day or the next day (excluding mail transit time).
  • Specific delivery contract (Section 2(ha)): This refers to contracts for specific qualities/types of goods where delivery happens during a specified future period (usually beyond the 11-day window).
  • Non-transferable specific delivery contract (Section 2(ca)): This is a specific delivery contract where the rights or documents of title (like warehouse receipts) cannot be transferred to a third party.
  • Transferable specific delivery contract (Section 2(k)): This is a specific delivery contract where the rights or documents of title are capable of being transferred to other parties.

4. Key Concept Takeaway

For SEBI Grade A, remember the "11-Day Rule":

  • Ready Delivery Contract (Goods): Settlement within 11 days.
  • Spot Delivery Contract (Securities): Settlement on Same day / Next day.
  • If a contract for goods goes beyond 11 days, it typically moves into the category of a Forward Contract or a Specific Delivery Contract.

main_question: Where a person dies, which of the following cannot be done against legal representative, as per SCRA?

Continuance of proceeding for levy of penalty against the deceased.
Liability for payment of penalty which has been imposed before the death of deceased.
Initiation of proceeding for refund and recovery
All can be done
answer_solution_english:
Section 23JC of SCRA –

Continuance of proceedings.—Where a person dies, his legal representative shall be liable to pay any sum which the deceased would have been liable to pay, if he had not died, in the like manner and to the same extent as the deceased:

Provided that, in case of any penalty payable under this Act, a legal representative shall be liable only in case the penalty has been imposed before the death of the deceased person.

(2) For the purposes of sub-section (1),—

(a) any proceeding for disgorgement, refund or an action for recovery before the Recovery Officer under this Act, except a proceeding for levy of penalty, initiated against the deceased before his death shall be deemed to have been initiated against the legal representative, and may be continued against the legal representative from the stage at which it stood on the date of the death of the deceased and all the provisions of this act shall apply accordingly;

(3) Every legal representative shall be personally liable for any sum payable by him in his capacity as legal representative if, while his liability for such sum remains undercharged, he creates a charge on or disposes of or pasts with any assets of the estate of the deceased, which are in, or may come into, his possession, but such liability shall be limited to the value of the asset so charged, disposed of or parted with.

(4) The liability of a legal representative under this section shall, be limited to the extent to which the estate of the decreased is capable of meeting the liability.

answer_solution_english: Two years preceding the insolvency commencement date, Explanation: Section 43-Preferential transactions and relevant time: (4) A preference shall be deemed to be given at a relevant time, if— (a) it is given to a related party (other than by reason only of being an employee), during the period of two years preceding the insolvency commencement date; or (b) a preference is given to a person other than a related party during the period of one year preceding the insolvency commencement date.

main_question: Under the IBC the liquidator shall receive or collect the claims of creditors within a period of ___________ from the date of the commencement of the liquidation process.
options: Seven days
One month
Thirty days

Ninety days

main_question: The term resolution professional has been defined under the IBC as_______________
options: An insolvency professional appointed to conduct the corporate insolvency resolution process
An insolvency professional appointed to conduct the prepackaged insolvency resolution process

An insolvency professional appointed to conduct the corporate insolvency resolution process or the prepackaged insolvency resolution process, as the case may be, does not include an interim resolution professional
