main_question: Under the Companies Act, 2013, which of the following combinations correctly identifies the minimum requirements for the formation and management of a Public Company?
options: Minimum 2 Members and Minimum 2 Directors.
Minimum 7 Members and Minimum 2 Directors.
Minimum 7 Members and Minimum 3 Directors.
Minimum 10 Members and Minimum 3 Directors.
Minimum 7 Members and Minimum 1 Director.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: Option 3.

Minimum Membership (Section 3)

The Act categorizes companies based on the minimum number of people required to sign the Memorandum of Association (MoA):

• Public Company: 7 or more persons.

• Private Company: 2 or more persons.

• One Person Company (OPC): 1 person

main_question: Under Section 271 of the Companies Act, 2013, read with Section 357, when is the winding up of a company by the Tribunal deemed to commence?
options: On the date the Tribunal passes the final winding up order.
On the date the Official Liquidator takes possession of the company's books and assets.
At the time of the presentation of the petition for the winding up.
On the date the resolution for winding up is passed by the shareholders.
On the date the company is struck off from the Register of Companies (ROC).
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 3

Winding Up by the Tribunal (Section 357(2))- Where a petition for winding up is presented to the Tribunal, the winding up is deemed to commence from the very moment the petition was presented.

This prevents directors from siphoning off assets or making fraudulent preferences between the time the petition is filed and the final order is passed.

Any disposition of property or transfer of shares made after the presentation of the petition is void unless the Tribunal orders otherwise.

main_question: Under Section 4 of the Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) Act, 2008, what is the legal relationship between the provisions of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, and an LLP?
options: The Indian Partnership Act, 1932, applies to LLPs unless a specific agreement states otherwise.
The provisions of the Indian Partnership Act, 1932, shall not apply to a limited liability partnership.
The Indian Partnership Act applies only to the 'Designated Partners' of the LLP.
The Central Government may, by notification, make the Indian Partnership Act applicable to LLPs.
Provisions of the Indian Partnership Act apply to LLPs only for the purpose of taxation.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 2

The LLP Act, 2008, was specifically designed to provide the benefits of a corporate body (limited liability and perpetual succession) while retaining the flexibility of a partnership. To maintain this "corporate" nature, it was necessary to legally decouple it from the old partnership law.

main_question: Under Section 7 of the Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) Act, 2008, which of the following statements correctly describes the mandatory requirements for Designated Partners?
options: Every LLP must have at least three designated partners, of whom all must be Indian residents.
An LLP must have at least two designated partners who are individuals, and both must be residents in India.
An LLP must have at least two designated partners who are individuals, and at least one of them must be a resident in India.
Only individuals who are also shareholders in a public company can be appointed as designated partners.
There is no requirement for a designated partner to be an Indian resident, provided they hold a valid DIN.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: Option 3.

The "Designated Partner" is a unique feature of the LLP structure, acting as the primary point of contact for regulatory compliance, similar to a Director in a company.

The "Two Individual" Rule

Every LLP must have at least two designated partners who are individuals.

If a body corporate (like a Company or another LLP) is a partner in the LLP, it must nominate an individual to act as its designated partner.

main_question: Under Section 152 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023, which of the following acts is punishable as an 'Act endangering sovereignty, unity and integrity of India'?
options: Bringing hatred or contempt toward the Government established by law in India through spoken or written words.
Purposely or knowingly exciting secession, armed rebellion, or subversive activities through electronic communication or use of financial means.
Endangering the sovereignty and unity of India by encouraging feelings of separatist activities.
Both 2 and 3.
All of the above.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 4

Section 152 represents a major legislative shift. While it covers similar ground to the old Sedition law, the language is broader and the penalties are more severe.

The BNS has moved away from protecting the "Government established by law" from criticism. Instead, the offense now triggers only when the Sovereignty, Unity, and Integrity of India are at risk.

main_question: A makes an attempt to steal jewels by breaking open a box, but finds after opening it that the box is empty. Under the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023, what is the legal liability of A?
options: A is guilty of 'Theft' under Section 303.
A has committed no offence because the 'factual impossibility' of the act (empty box) negates the crime.
A is guilty of 'Attempt to commit an offence' under Section 62.
A is only guilty of 'Mischief' for breaking the box.
A is guilty of 'House-breaking' under Section 331.
answer_solution_english:
The Correct Answer: 3

In criminal law, "factual impossibility" (the fact that there were no jewels to steal) does not provide a defense against a charge of Attempt. As long as the intention was present and an act was done toward the commission of the crime, the offense is complete.

main_question: Under Section 351(1) of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023, the act of threatening another with injury to their person, reputation, or property with the intent to cause alarm or to compel them to perform an act they are not legally bound to do, is defined as:
options: Extortion
Defamation
Criminal Intimidation
Coercion
Assault
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 3

The Nature of the Threat

The threat must be directed toward:

  • The Person (physical harm).
  • The Reputation (blackmail or character assassination).
  • The Property (damage to assets).
  • The threat can also be directed toward someone in whom the target is interested (e.g., threatening a person's child).

main_question: Under Section 356 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023, which of the following scenarios would NOT qualify as an exception to the offense of Defamation?
options: Publicly criticizing the conduct of an officer in the discharge of their public functions.
Publishing a substantially true report of the proceedings of the Securities Appellate Tribunal (SAT).
Making a sarcastic and mocking imputation about a person's character, intending it to be understood ironically to lower their credit.
Cautioning a family member against a particular stockbroker in good faith for their financial protection.
Accusing a person of a crime they actually committed, where such accusation is for the public good.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 3

Under Explanation 3 of Section 356, BNS, the law explicitly clarifies that an imputation may amount to defamation even if it is expressed ironically. For example, if a person says, "Oh, Suresh is a very 'honest' man; he never stole anyone's watch," while knowing Suresh is a thief, the ironic use of "honest" does not save the speaker from liability.

main_question: Under Section 316(1) of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023, what offense is committed by a person who, being entrusted with property or having dominion over it, dishonestly misappropriates it, converts it to their own use, or uses it in violation of a legal contract?
options: Theft
Criminal Misappropriation of Property
Extortion
Criminal Breach of Trust
Cheating
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 4

The Essential Ingredient: Entrustment

Unlike theft or misappropriation, CBT must begin with a lawful relationship.

Entrustment: The property must have been voluntarily handed over to the offender by the owner.

Dominion: The offender must have control over the property (e.g., a Company Director has dominion over the company's bank accounts)

main_question: A, a police officer, is legally duty-bound to prevent robbery. Instead of preventing it, A abets the commission of a robbery. However, the robbery is not actually committed. Under Section 52 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023, what is the maximum punishment A is liable for?
options: One-fourth of the longest term of imprisonment provided for robbery, and fine.
One-half of the longest term of imprisonment provided for robbery, and fine.
One-third of the longest term of imprisonment provided for robbery, and fine.
Imprisonment for life.
A is not liable because the robbery was not committed.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 2

General Abetment vs. Public Servant Abetment

The law imposes a much higher standard of conduct on public servants. The punishment varies based on who the abettor is:

Section 51 (General): If an ordinary person abets a crime and it is not committed, they are liable for one-fourth (1/4) of the longest term for that offense.

Section 52 (Public Servant): If a public servant, whose duty is to prevent that specific offense, abets it and it is not committed, the punishment is doubled to one-half (1/2) of the longest term.

main_question: Under Section 20 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS), 2023, which of the following acts is protected by the principle of 'Doli Incapax'?
options: An act done by a child above 10 years but under 14 years with mature understanding.
An act done by a person who is involuntarily intoxicated.
An act done by a child under seven years of age.
An act done by a person of unsound mind who understands the nature of the act.
An act done under a mistake of law.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 3

Absolute Immunity: Section 20 BNS

  • Rule: Nothing is an offence which is done by a child under seven years of age.
  • Reasoning: At this age, the law presumes the child is physically and mentally incapable of forming the mens rea (guilty intention) necessary for a crime. No evidence can be presented to prove otherwise.

main_question: According to the definition provided in Section 2(11) of the BNS, 2023, an act is NOT considered to have been done in 'Good Faith' if it is done:
options: With excessive caution.
Without due care and attention.
With honest but mistaken intentions.
By a person authorized under a special law.
In the absence of a legal warrant.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 2

The Two Ingredients: Care and Attention

For an act to be in "Good Faith" under the BNS, the doer must prove they exercised:

  • Due Care: The level of caution that a reasonable person would take in that specific situation.
  • Due Attention: A deliberate application of the mind to the facts and risks involved.

main_question: Under Regulation 3(2) of the SEBI (SAST) Regulations, 2011, an acquirer who already holds 25% or more of the voting rights in a target company (but less than the maximum permissible non-public shareholding) is permitted to acquire additional voting rights without triggering a mandatory open offer, provided such acquisition does not exceed what limit?
options: 2% of voting rights in a financial year.
3% of voting rights in a financial year.
5% of voting rights in a financial year.
10% of voting rights in a financial year.
25% of voting rights in a financial year.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 3

If an acquirer already holds between 25% and 75% (the typical maximum non-public shareholding), they are allowed a "creeping" window. They can acquire up to 5% additional voting rights in any single financial year (April to March) without making an open offer.

The "Gross" Rule: SEBI calculates this 5% on a gross basis. This means you cannot buy 5%, sell 2%, and then buy another 2% in the same year. The moment your total purchases hit 5%, the limit is exhausted, regardless of any intermittent sales.

main_question: Under Section 23 of the Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita (BNSS), 2023, what is the maximum sentencing authority of the Court of a Chief Judicial Magistrate (CJM)?
options: Any sentence authorized by law including death.
Imprisonment for a term not exceeding 10 years.
Any sentence authorized by law except death, imprisonment for life, or imprisonment for a term exceeding seven years.
Imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years and a fine of ₹50,000.
Imprisonment for a term not exceeding one year and a fine of ₹10,000.
answer_solution_english:
Correct Answer: 3

Chief Judicial Magistrate (CJM) - Section 23(1)

The CJM holds the highest power among the Magistracy. They can pass any sentence authorized by law EXCEPT:

  • Death Penalty
  • Imprisonment for Life
  • Imprisonment for a term exceeding 7 years
